normalised: The price of tomatoes in Delhi's Azadpur Mandi skyrocketed to rupee one hundred and twenty per kilogram recently, leaving many household budgets strained. Meena aunty from Lajpat Nagar was visibly upset. "Last week, I bought one kilogram for rupees forty only. Now it's triple! How will I make my tomato chutney?" she lamented while squeezing a slightly bruised tomato.

unnormalised: Across town in Mumbai, the Dadar vegetable market saw similar price hikes. Brinjal, usually priced at Rs. 30/kg, was selling for Rs. 60/kg. "Monsoon has affected the supply," explained a vendor, wiping sweat off his brow with a gamcha. "Transportation costs have also gone up, adding Rs. 5/km to the cost." He gestured towards a pile of soggy spinach, "Even the palak is Rs. 40 for 250 gms."
normalised: Across town in Mumbai, the Dadar vegetable market saw similar price hikes. Brinjal, usually priced at rupees thirty per kilogram, was selling for rupees sixty per kilogram. "Monsoon has affected the supply," explained a vendor, wiping sweat off his brow with a gamcha. "Transportation costs have also gone up, adding rupees five per kilometer to the cost." He gestured towards a pile of soggy spinach, "Even the palak is rupees forty for two hundred and fifty grams."

unnormalised: Meanwhile, online grocery platforms are also feeling the heat. BigBasket and Grofers are showing prices ranging from Rs. 90/kg to Rs. 110/kg for tomatoes, depending on the quality. Many users are switching to smaller quantities or exploring substitutes. Some families in Chennai have reportedly started using tamarind pulp instead of tomatoes in their sambhar.

Many users are switching to smaller quantities or exploring substitutes. Some families in Chennai have reportedly started using tamarind pulp instead of tomatoes in their sambhar.

unnormalised: The rise in prices isn't limited to vegetables. Pulses like toor dal are now selling at Rs. 130 per kg, up from Rs. 110/kg a month ago. Cooking oil prices have also seen a slight increase, with a 5-liter can of sunflower oil costing around Rs. 750. A packet of Amul butter of 500 gms is now priced at Rs. 300.

A packet of Amul butter of five hundred grams is now priced at rupees three hundred.

unnormalised: Traders attribute the price rise to a combination of factors, including monsoon-related disruptions, increased fuel costs, and hoarding by some unscrupulous elements. "The govt. needs to take strict action," said a wholesale trader at the Bengaluru market. "These price fluctuations are affecting everyone, especially the lower income groups."
